When is the tensor product of linearly independent families linearly independent?
This is not always true, and essentially you are asking P⊗M→N⊗MP \otimes M \to N \otimes MP⊗M→N⊗M to be injective if P→NP \to NP→N is injective and PPP is free.

Let’s call such MMM good modules (if P⊗M↪N⊗MP \otimes M \hookrightarrow N \otimes MP⊗M↪N⊗M for all NNN and all free P⊆NP \subseteq NP⊆N). Is there a better characterization of them? Here are some facts I know about them:

  1. Flat modules are good.
  2. Submodules of good modules are good.
  3. (Potentially infinite) direct product of good modules are good. (Because P⊗∏iMi↪∏iP⊗MiP \otimes \prod_i M_i \hookrightarrow \prod_i P \otimes M_iP⊗∏i​Mi​↪∏i​P⊗Mi​)
  4. Good modules are torsion free. (By looking at (a)⊆R(a) \subseteq R(a)⊆R for a∈R0a \in R^0a∈R0)

  5. Over integral domains, torsion free modules are good (Because M↪k⊗RMM \hookrightarrow k \otimes_R MM↪k⊗R​M with k=Frac(R)k = \mathrm{Frac}(R)k=Frac(R) and k⊗RMk \otimes_R Mk⊗R​M is kkk-flat).

  6. There are torsion free modules that are not good. Then MMM is torsion free, R→⋅e2MR \xrightarrow{\cdot e_2} MR⋅e2​​M is injective, but M→⋅⊗e2M⊗MM \xrightarrow{\cdot \otimes e_2} M \otimes MM⋅⊗e2​​M⊗M is not injective because e4⊗e2=ye1⊗e2=e1⊗ye2=e1⊗xe3=xe1⊗e3=0e_4 \otimes e_2 = ye_1 \otimes e_2 = e_1 \otimes ye_2 = e_1 \otimes xe_3 = xe_1 \otimes e_3 = 0e4​⊗e2​=ye1​⊗e2​=e1​⊗ye2​=e1​⊗xe3​=xe1​⊗e3​=0.
